Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: The client’s case involves important disputes that require careful representation
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open to the client’s file, legal arguments swirling in my mind. My phone buzzed with a message from my mother: “Can we talk tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I glanced at the clock—court was in the morning, and I still needed to review the evidence, prepare my notes, and anticipate the opposing counsel’s moves. My client was counting on me; their future depended on my focus and skill. But my parents needed me, too. I could hear my mother’s voice, soft and uncertain, asking if everything was okay at home. I was their child, the one who checked in, who listened, who tried to hold the family together. The weight of their unspoken worries pressed on me, just as the responsibility to my client did. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the home I came from and the person I was becoming. I stared at the screen, torn, feeling the impossible pull of both worlds, knowing I couldn’t give either the attention they deserved at the same time.
